pros:
+ Beautiful scenery, the campus is a wonderful place to take a stroll during lunch or from meeting to meeting
+ Pay is on par for those used to working in higher education or nonprofit settings
+ There are plenty of opportunities to gain experience by teaching a course, leading a program or project
cons:
- The hours that exempt staff members are expected to work are plainly exploitative. It is normal for staff to work 10-12 hour days multiple times per week. When I spoke to my supervisor about comp time after working long hours on numerous days, she informed me that she had worked 21 straight days and reminded me that I was exempt. I'm not sure why working long hours is so pervasive, but it is a recipe for burnout. 
- An atmosphere of toxicity that could be described as gossipy, racist, and elitist, all while parading around in a righteous attitude. 
- An excessive amount of initiatives being taken on, one after the other. My supervisor seemed focused on applying for grants and front loading work into that part and as soon as the program started running, her focus would shift into the next program without much thought being invested into the maintenance and quality control of previous programs. I'm not quite sure what was the point of this since it caused plenty of friction within workers and departments.

review_title: Stable Employer but Confusing and Quick Return to Work
pros: Good supportive coworkers and clear communication of strategic goals. A very stable environment with few layoffs or restructures. Many employees have been there 10 years +.
cons: While the university was great protecting us and letting us work from home the last year and a half, in July my department gave me just 2 weeks notice for return to work 5 days a week. The lack of communication or discussion was surprising given what I see in other employers and industries. My department at least is requiring 5 days a week even though I do not meet with clients, faculty, or students and all of my job can be done from home. I would have hoped their would have been some flexibility to work 1-2 days from home given our department's increased productivity the last year, but there is not.

cons: Doesn't live up to its mission. Racist/Toxic/Sexist environments are everywhere. It's like a wildfire.

review_title: If it was for the PPO I would have gone elsewhere for work
pros: The only good thing about this place is that they have tuition benefits, though the majors one would want to ideally chose are not covered. Very few supervisors actually know what they are doing.
cons: SERIOUS LACK OF PAY FOR THE WORK! If you look around the city of Chicago at other universities and even community colelges you will see that Loyola fails in compensation. Once within a certain department you are stuck and it seems as though you can never get out, even after 10+ years of dedication to the university. You can apply for as many jobs that you qualify for and still no interview calls. Funny how one department seems to be blacklisted and employees in it can never move out of it. Also MANY supervisors break multiple rules and never get any sort of repremand for doing so, continuing to be allowed to do whatever they please and treat people any way that they wish.

job_title: Campus Safety Officer in Chicago, IL
pros: Benefits are good but other than that there isn't much to look forward to. There was a time when going to work was fun but at the end it was hell of boys club
cons: Happily I left the university's campus safety department! People who have worked in the department far longer than the director's buddies are being treated horribly and being forced out. The ones that they can't force out are given last minute shift changes and day off groups despite specifically saying they can't do that, leaving some to go sleepless some days because they have other commitments whether family or school. A majority of the supervisors are male and have zero qualms about making sexist remarks and think that mental illness is a joke. Despite complaints, it seems bad officers are still going unpunished and good ones are being treated like they break rules. The work environment is toxic here, so happy to be on to better things, where I get paid what my skills are worth. Campus Safety has yet to see a cost of living wage raise, yet they have money to send people off to training they don't need.

pros: Loyola is a great working environment!
cons: There is no con really!

review_title: Getting your foot in the door is a step in the right direction.
pros: LUC has a great benefits package and for the most part offers a lot of institutional support to individual employees.  After you've been there a year you can take classes for free from various programs, and a spouse gets a steep discount as well.  Most managers are flexible and there's plenty of space between my personal life and my work life because of that flexibility.  I feel like I've done some genuinely good work here and make people's lives better because of it, something I was searching for when I found this job.
cons: Like any typical larger company or univ, communication between departments and schools can be found lacking.  It takes a few extra messages or calls to get someone out of their comfort zone if you're looking to try something new or get them to buy into what you're doing.  There are times when it feels like no one knows what anybody else is doing and occasionally wires of communication get crossed because of it.

pros:
Lakeshore Campus is a beautiful place to work in.
The department I work in is filled with kind, mostly introverted people. 
I've had the great fortune of working under a manager who led with Theory Y, or "the belief that, given appropriate working conditions, most people perform well." Unfortunately, since there isn't much room to talk openly about what higher-ups are not doing well, my manager's manager overworked her and she has since left Loyola.
cons:
There is no room for growth here, that's why it can be quite be a frustrating for ambitious people to stay satisfied for long. I say this as someone who has worked here for three years.
It's very hard to introduce innovative ideas because if it doesn't align with what the leader thinks is a good idea, then you're out of luck. 
I now work with a couple of managers that operate under Theory X, or the misguided assumption that people are not inherently motivated to work. 
Also, part-time workers here do not qualify for tuition reimbursement nor paid holidays.

pros: The people and passion of Loyola make me want to continue working here. I feel like I can be a part of a great community when I'm on campus. I like the students and fellow faculty. The dean of my department is someone I admire and want to continue to work with.
cons: On a 1-year contract, I have not heard if there will be funding for the following year and this is apparently the norm. Another instructor told me he has been in 1-year contracts for 5 years and is sometimes told just before the fall semester that they can renew his contract. It makes it hard to decide if I should take another position or hold out for this job that I love (but might not be available come fall).

pros: Benefits are pretty good, dental could be better; some of the students are amazing to talk to and made working here bearable
cons: EXTREMELY high turn over; HR is even slower at allowing hiring to be done; pay is terrible compared to other universities in Chicago; the poor security is totally overworked and it shows on their faces that they are exhausted, plenty know that their supervisors are nasty people that make them do things far outside their duties; temperature regulation is terrible; waste money on new buildings without classroom that were supposed to be for classes. Does NOT value diversity in the least!

review_title: Good position if you want to develop skills for the future
pros: It provides great opportunities to pick up on skills that will be useful to you in the future, in addition to valuable workplace experience and solid references. You will be able to network with peers and this will also be beneficial for you in the future.
cons: Long hours at times. Often management does not understand the difficulty of certain tasks or the business of Resident Assistant schedules. This is probably a commonplace at all university Resident Assistant staffs. The key is communication. Often, Resident Assistants will not communicate their difficulties with peers or management and they will be worse off as a result. Also, make sure to never burn any bridges and always be professional with everyone, as assignments are at least one year long.

pros: The only pro would be the tution assistance (note that the graduate benefits will get taxed)
cons:
If you are looking for a work place to begin a career and grow within the company through an established promotion system, this is not the place for you.  No promotion system in place for the Finance division.  Many qualified candidates within the division but many decisions are based on favoritism and politics.  

Also, the management is very old-school and set on old ways. 

The merit increases are fairly low and the salary is below market.  

No opportunity to work from home.

pros: I worked in the biology department, which is outstanding. There are no graduate students, so they hire under-employed Chicago PhDs to do jobs that would go to TAs in larger schools. All of my colleagues demanded excellence from their students, and were willing to work themselves sick to help their students achieve it.
cons: There's low pay and no job security because you work semester-to-semester. Their policy of forbidding full-time work to laboratory instructors means that you'll need another job to survive in Chicago.

pros: Great people in my dept, pleasure to work with. Pretty campus.
cons: Loyola moves in spurts and jumps. Either nothing changes at all, or it's done so suddenly and without consideration that you question whether any thought or planning actually went into the decisions. Sometimes it works out well, sometimes it does not.

review_title: Loyola is a positive place to work
pros:
They are truly dedicated to their mission of providing a transformative education and the Jesuit principles.
The staff and faculty care about their work, the students, and each other.
It is a cheerful, friendly, and motivating environment.
cons:
The location is hard to get to for many employees.
There is a strong dichotomy between life as a staff member versus life as a faculty member- they are not equal players.
The strong ties to the Jesuit organization is both good and bad, depending more on politics than anything else.

pros: I really enjoyed how clean the office was that I worked in. I also enjoyed how short my work days were, this allowed me time to study for my classes. I was treated well and in a professional manner.
cons: The only thing I disliked was the politics of the office. I would've liked equal treatment from everyone no matter what. I felt that new people do not get treated as well as veteran student workers and I think this is wrong and shouldn't be allowed.

pros: Loyola is a remarkable place, with high-quality programs and a well-defined mission that balances well a dedication to excellence in education with a commitment to social justice and serving others as the ultimate objective. Innovation and thoughtful planning.
cons: As at many universities, silos and specialization sometimes impede communication, but there is a remarkable understanding of mission and values across the institution. The students are amazing and the faculty inspiring, for the most part.

review_title: Job satisfaction at a University depends entirely on your department.
job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Chicago, IL
pros: Good benefits. Will pay for your education at Loyola. Low pressure environment. Very casual dress code. Flexible regarding working hours and time off.
cons: Pay is ridiculously low. People never get fired so incompetence runs rampant. Do not expect to make any changes to status quo. Technology is not a priority in some departments.

job_title: IT Student Worker in Chicago, IL
pros:
- IT department is invested in your professional development. Staff assist you with resume building and networking
- Competitive hourly raise with chance to grow based on skill set and contribution
- Positive work environment. Co-workers and direct supervisors are down to earth
- Work-life balance! Especially as student workers we are students first and employees second. Supervisors know and respect that. Nonetheless, we are rightfully expected to uphold our professional duties by being on time and communicative re: our class schedule and extracurricular obligations.
cons: - None that I can think of. This is one of the best departments to work for at Loyola University. Our feedback is taken seriously so the department is always growing.

pros: As a graduate student pursuing my MBA, a graduate scholar position was critical to my success at Loyola Chicago. Not only did it lower my debt load, but it also allowed me to gain professional relationships with the faculty and staff.
cons: Loyola Chicago, like any university really, is highly political and full of egotistical people.  With every teacher gunning for tenure, there seems to be a high level of tension at times throughout the school floors.

pros: The salary was  good and coworkers were by in large okay to deal with.
cons: I was employed as a contract IT Consultant and mostly unboxed monitors and labeled computers. I had my only review of my work from a fellow contractor, who told me he wanted to be the only contractor left in Loyola. I was never on boarded by management or given feedback. My fellow employees worked didn't work well as a team in the traditional sense of the word. I labelled most of the computers at Loyola, but got fired for working too slowly.

pros: Fast-paced environment involved with the greater Loyola community. Additionally, the networking that occurs is an opportunity to find a job post-graduation
cons: At times there are opportunities that can be challenging due to the Jesuit ideology for social justice. Individuals that do not buy into social justice might have difficulty with this work environment if they tend not to bite their tongues.

pros: Love the campus. Students are professional (by and large). Great facilities. It's nice to work for a school where budget constraints are less of an issue.
cons: The usual academic nonsense. They rely heavily on adjunct faculty, but treat us as second-class citizens. They pay us poorly (but I guess that's happening everywhere nowadays). Departmental infighting is an issue.

job_title: Grad Reference Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Great environment, teamwork, opportunity to learn how to do your own research. If it is not busy hours you can do your own homework, but be ready to stop it any time when patrons or librarians need your help. Anytime you need help, you can ask any librarian for help.
cons: During spring winter or summer brake you probably can't work full time since other students (your coworkers) would like some extra hours too. During some weeks the library is closed and during some weeks they close earlier, so you will have less hours during that week.

pros: Good pay and benefits. Apartment that comes with the position is kept up well. Autonomy to do what you want within your building. Initiative is supported by department leadership if you have an idea you want to carry out. Committed and hard-working employees.
cons: There's been a lot of change in the department in the last year as they've been searching for a director, but if you're able to roll with change, it's been nice to keep things fresh.

review_title: I loved the work I did, but I was dissatisfied working under a moody lab manager.
pros: I loved the science, every aspect of it. The medical and dental benefits were good, and employees received 10 paid holidays each year, in addition to 2 weeks paid vacation.
cons: As it was only the lab manager and me working in the lab, when the manager was in a foul mood (typically 3 days out of 5), the atmosphere was tense and unpleasant. It is amazing how the lack of basic social amenities like "Good Morning" and "Thank You" can negatively impact the workplace.

job_title: Hospital Access Representative in Maywood, IL
pros: Longevity available at the company as it is a leading trauma one institute. Working in the admitting department definitely provides personal growth as it is a challenging position and you learn a lot about yourself. Many of my co-workers have been employees for extended periods of time. I enjoyed working with them and getting knowledge from them.
cons: Bonus structure was not very great. Sometimes it was difficult to transfer from departments due to management. It is a high pressure position with little financial reward. Sometimes the stress from the department and from the management can be a bit overwhelming.

job_title: Circulation Desk Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: The staff I worked with was friendly, diverse, and supportive.  I learned valuable skills working in the library.
cons: The only downside in comparison to other part-time student jobs through the university was that I was not able to just sit and work on homework while at the Circulation Desk like some other positions allow.  This was a small disadvantage, though, considering I loved the work and it was a job after all!

review_title: OK job but not really a career.
pros: There is free tuition after a year with the University.  I worked as a desk receptionist for Admissions.  It was for the most part, a very simple job.  However, around the beginning of the school year it was a nightmare dealing with crazed parents and first-time students.  You meet a lot of people through admissions so it is a great way to network.  For the right person, upward mobility is greatly possible due to the influx of university professionals you come in contact with on a daily basis.  In my position there was very little micromanaging. Most people are very calm and good natured due to the intellectual environment.
cons: At times the position was very boring.  You do the same things day in and day out.  A big portion of my job was returning phone calls.  You answer the same questions all the time and it can get pretty monotonous. Also, it is very important to get people on the phone to relay messages.  You are playing phone tag a lot of times with parents and university officials to get basic questions answered which can get frustrating over time.  The corporate culture in my department was extremely customer-centric.  Thus, you had to bend over backwards to make sure the customer was happy, which usually meant going out of your way.  For certain individuals this can quickly become annoying. Especially when parents/students do not do what they are supposed to and then you have to find a solution as soon as possible to get the student admitted.

pros: -Great experience doing work in-house, great pay (with raises), flexibility for students, awesome supervisors that really cared, a great staff with connections in Chicago that will try to get you a job post-graduation
cons: -Some days were slower than others, particularly when more interns were hired to do the same amount of work, and other days would be much busier

review_title: . I was lucky to find a job that is centered around student life and campus

Many of the people are nice & mean well.

cons: The business school is poorly managed.  The technical support is patchy at best. The tight budgets create a struggle to get basic amenities:  classroom equipment, spending accounts, TA's, travel, parking, administrative support, etc. Decisions about everything from curriculum changes to health insurance are made behind closed doors. The high turnover rate makes it difficult to establish a network & friendships. Salaries do not go very far in a city like Chicago. Anyone who questions policy does not keep their position for long.

pros: Good students, smart people, and an excellent place to teach. Beautiful campus and nice teaching facilities. Nice for anyone starting out in academics.
cons: Some of the other professors do not know what they are talking about, are ignorant or self-absorbed. Pay is alright, but benefits make up for it.

pros: Awesome co-workers. There were times when we forgot we were at work.
cons: Horrible upper-management and calls from CEOs who have never been down to our department. We were outsourced without so much warning.

pros:
Beautiful Campus, right on Lake Michigan. Can't beat it. The Water Tower Campus, the few times I was allowed to go down there (I wasn't important enough to be given many opportunities), is also in a neat area of the city.

Easy accesss to Public Transportation. Loyola has a stop on Red Line. The 147/151 is right across the street.

Solid Benefits Package, but don't confuse with COMPENSATION. Again, I can't stress this enough: Do not confuse with compensation.
cons:
Lack of Career Development. You can literally beg to try and do anything to try and get some kind of meaningful experience relevant to possibly moving up and you won't even be told no. You just will get a phony smile and a "good idea", only to leave the office and never hear about anything. I've never seen a department that has people volunteer to do extra work and that turn out to be a negative for them. It was like bizaro world.

Internal Promotion. Doesn't happen in this department...well, unless you were an outsider to begin with. To watch people time and time get brought in from the outside for positions applied and qualified for really tells you all you need to know about a company. You also have to laugh at hearing management talk about bringing counselors in for certain positions when capable people are already there. 

"Bill Lumberg" Style Phony Management Team. If you're an advisor you'll get told in team meetings in front of everyone to "zone out" for a bit as the next piece of information about to be discussed won't concern you, all with a bright wide smile by "management". It's very degrading and disrespectful, and makes you feel pretty worthless to the team. 

Embarrassing Compensation. I get it, you don't get into Higher Ed for the money. But does the department realize we are living in Chicago, not Mississippi? Shameful pay. They ask you to volunteer to work certain weekend events, but really, you have to. But do you get paid overtime as an hourly employee? Of course not! You'll get told to go home early on other days of the week.

pros: Very talented and committed faculty, purpose-driven students, and dedicated staff.
cons: As at most places, communication could be better. Recently, the president and top management seem to have taken this to heart and more communication and outreach it taking place.  It is a challenge at a three-campus, decentralized university with tons of management layers.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Melrose Park, IL
pros: Loyola University Chicago has a great benefits for their employees. People that I working for Loyola are open, supportive, and always willing to help.
cons: The biggest issue with Loyola University Chicago is salary. The salary levels are far below the average for Chicago area.

review_title: Very bad at the Derm/peptide lab
job_title: Research Lab Manager in Maywood, IL
pros: The campus in Maywood was excellent. I loved having the gym, multiple places to eat and some nature nearby. Also the equipment and research facilities were modern and well managed.
cons:
Tldr: Derm/peptide lab at Loyola University was a terrible place to work

Essentially, working at the Derm/peptide lab was a complete nightmare. I’m sure there are functional labs at Loyola, but the one where I spent 12 months made me completely lose confidence, and it took me 2 years to recover. 
Before Loyola, I worked as a process chemist in an HPLC lab and had a successful 3 years before deciding to start studying for the MCAT. At that point I decided to leverage my technical skills to work amongst clinicians at Loyola. Pay was bad ($17/hr), but I thought I could gain experience and apply for med schools within the year. Turned out to be the worst year of my life. Once I was fired from Loyola I studied computer science at home, applied for the most selective coding bootcamp, and today I’m close to 2 years into a blossoming engineering career making 3x my Loyola salary and feel empowered to grow as an engineer. I’m all the more grateful for my current position, because working at Loyola was a so bad. 
To begin with, it’s still hard to think back to those times. The worst memories at Derm/peptide lab were while working closely with her PhD candidate. She was a lovely international student who was constantly in a state of panic due to the severity of mental abuse at the lab. She had it much worse, because her husband’s visa was dependent on her employment at Loyola. She was worried about her status, and it was palpable. So the midnight assays and 12 hour days seemed fairly necessary. This was the general tone of the lab, perfection or deportation. And as my only coworker, the PhD candidate tried not to transfer her immense stress onto me, but it was impossible when she had just been berated, and her eyes were still puffy from a private cry in the bathroom. Mistakes are made, and in a productive workplace you reflect on how and why those mistakes were made. In the Derm/peptide lab, a mistake is considered an act of sabotage! Everyone in the lab had to work together but leadership made it feel like we were working against each other. Belittling and gaslighting was the norm. I never thought, I’d be the type to cry on the commute from work. Friends and family begged me to quit, but I felt like I was in debt and couldn’t leave until I deserved a letter of recommendation. I hope that the P.I. learns from her mistakes. She might one day have a lab with many researchers, but I cringe at the idea. This review is specific to the Derm/peptide lab, but look out for signs of a toxic workplace. It’s the right move to leave if you’re only digging a ditch.
